title: Why has Sri Lanka historically never been a part of India despite its proximity to the Indian sub-continent? - Quora

response.answer_text: Although Sri Lanka emerged as a separate country, it would not be completely correct to state that Sri Lanka was never the part of India. Right from the time of Ramayana, Sri Lanka finds mention in Indian texts. If you turn the pages of history, you would find that Sri Lanka was being conquered by the South Indian kings. Connection with India: According to Mahavamsa, a Sri Lankan text, it is believed that Prince Vijaya, who belonged to the kingdom of Kalinga was banished from his kingdom. During his exile, he landed in this island with his followers. Eventually he married a local girl and their children gave rise to the Pulinda race. Also, he married the princess of the Pandu kingdom and his followers married the maidens of the princess sent by the king. Their offspring gave rise to the Sinhalese people. Prince Vijaya is credited with the establishment of the Tambapanni kingdom. This period was followed by Anuradhapura period. Conquest of the Island Nation: There were multiple times when the island nation of Sri Lanka was invaded and conquered by South Indian kings. The Five Dravidians: Believed to be from the Pandyan kingdom, five Tamil chiefs overthrew the local king and ruled the kingdom for a span of 14 years after which they were defeated and the reign returned to the local king.The Cholas: Raja Raja Chola and Rajendra Chola also conquered the island kingdom and ruled over it for a span of 80 years after which they were defeated by the Sinhalese king. There were numerous battle between the Cholas and the rulers of Anuradhapura.Aryacakravarti dynasty: One of the major dynasties of Sri Lanka, Aryacakravarti dynasty, was set up by the Pandyans when they captured and established a kingdom, known as Jaffna kingdom. This dynasty went on to rule the kingdom for centuries to come and is recorded as one of the major dynasties in that era.British India and Ceylon: Ceylon was initially a Portuguese who were succeeded by the Dutch. Later, British overthrew the Dutch and took over the island. It became a new colony of the crown. India continued to be ruled by East India Company while Ceylon became the colony of the crown. However, India and Ceylon, although became part of the same crown later, were never merged. Reason could be either that natives of both the nations were different culturally, Ceylon was not as profitable as India or could be both. India and Sri Lanka have been sharing ties since ancient times. We could see some Indian influence on their culture as well. Although, Sri Lanka and India parted ways from the advent of British Raj, prior to that as history suggests, Sri Lanka did become an “extended” part of India for a considerable time.
